title: Painting, plastering costs skyrocket as Sydneysiders opt for renovations over relocations
text:
Sydney’s previous property boom, current shortage of houses for sale and record low interest rates have all combined to fuel a surge in renovations.

New bank research showed NSW homeowners were spending, on average, about $15,000 more on renovations than owners in Victoria and Queensland, with many improving their existing homes to avoid a gruelling search for a larger house.

The average spend was just over $60,000, according to Suncorp, and comes as property sales data showed there remains a shortage of larger family homes for sale, particularly four-bedroom houses.

And with demand for tradies ramping up, renovators said keeping costs down was becoming a challenge.

Average tradie charges for plastering and painting increased by more than 20 per cent over the past year, while the cost of getting concreting done went up by 17 per cent, Service Seeking data showed.

Prices for other common renovation jobs such as tiling, bathroom related works, plumbing and gardening increased by about 5 per cent.

Realestate.com.au chief economist Nerida Conisbee said renovations were becoming increasingly appealing for Sydney homeowners because most had a large amount of equity in their properties due to the nearly 75 per cent increase in home values over 2013-2017.

Low interest rates also meant homeowners could tap into that equity through a cheaper loan, she said.

Doing a renovation means they can avoid joining the battle for homes in a market with limited listings, where 20 per cent fewer homes were available for sale compared to a year ago.

“If you’re buying in the current market you’ll be very restricted,” Ms Conisbee said.

“Not much is getting listed for sale in some parts of Sydney so a lot of homeowners would be deciding a renovation would make more sense, especially with cheap credit.”

Suncorp general manager lending Glenn Haslam said government charges on property transactions were driving more people toward renovation.

“The grass isn’t always greener on the other side,” Mr Haslam said. “We’re seeing more Suncorp Bank customers borrow against their mortgage to renovate their house, which means they avoid having to pay stamp duty costs.”

Suburbs where homeowners most frequently drew on their equity to fund a renovation over the past year included Woolloomooloo, Lindfield, Surry Hills, Paddington and Winston Hills, according to Suncorp.

All were areas where listing numbers were down and auction clearance rates were between 75 and 80 per cent — normally an indicator of a hot market.

Mosman residents Bob and Melissa St Julian said they embarked on a full overhaul of their home after realising it would be the best route to getting a home “perfect” for their needs.

“We had already bought well in a good block and we figured in an area like Mosman adding value would be worth it,” Mr St Julian said.

The couple enlisted Mathieson Architects and B&M Building Group to gut their interior and opened the home to add more natural light, a project Mr St Julian admitted “cost a lot of money”.

“You wouldn’t recognise the home now, it’s so much better,” he said.

description: A shift in the Sydney housing market is fuelling a renovations bonanza, with research revealing some trades cashed in by upping their prices by more than 20 per cent over the past year.
